I swear they used to have decent support. But then they got bought, chewed up and spit out by Dell.

100% THIS! Dell ruins small & mid-sized solutions. I bought into the Sonicwall ecosystem in a major way, right about the time they got sucked in by Dell. Ditto the KACE KBOX and EqualLogic SANs. (Dell was on a buying spree around 2005-2009)

All 3 products were great up-and-coming solutions for small and mid-sized businesses with easy configuration & management, a good feature-set, and great performance for the price.

In the first year of ownership all seemed to prosper under Dell - expanding their product offerings and accelerating development. Then the Dell-specific software hooks started getting inserted. Next, the products began being twisted into specific niches - either around other Dell products or into areas that Dell figured they "needed" to be. ALL of the products' development and support either stalled out or became poor. A terrible shame!

SonicWall could've rivaled Meraki or Aruba if development had continued. They had next-gen firewall features before most others, with easier administration and easy VPN clients than the major name-brands at the time.

KBOX as an all-in-one IT support solution (licensing/asset-tracking, deployment, automation, helpdesk, etc) that outclassed products like ManageEngine, Spiceworks, Zoho, LANSweeper, PDQ, and Ninite - then stalled and fell behind most of them around 5 years ago.

And EqualLogic could have gone toe-to-toe with Nimble or Pure if they'd evolved forward into the SSD space instead of being relegated to a Dell backwater (to avoid cannibalizing sales of Dell's other - less good - SAN solutions).

I really cannot stand SonicWall products. I know they’re supposed to be industry leaders in network security and what not, but my experience is that they simply take run of the mill parts, install an unnecessarily complicated OS, charge way more for the product than it’s worth, and then charge a subscription fee just to keep the thing up-to-date. Even doing simple things, like port forwarding, on a SonicWall can be a lesson in frustration. You can use a dubiously helpful wizard to forward the port, but what if you want to undo the forward? Good luck tracking down the half-dozen or so changes made spread out across various settings and rules. I’ve worked directly with IP tables, and they’re easier to use than a SonicWall

You've only used them since about 2012, haven't you? They went downhill over time, as the dev teams seemed to get starved out and new releases were just stacking crap on top of crap; rather than cleaning things up, fixing bugs and incompatibilities, and improving the system (as earlier releases seemed to do).

And it sounds like you're an experienced Cisco ios user? The point of the SonicWall (at least, originally), was never to outclass a heavy-duty Cisco solution or be targeted at security experts. It was there for small to midsized businesses who didn't have much IT staff, who didn't have a ton of network-engineering experience. It allowed those businesses to easily set up something that could do limited NAT & forwarding, some Layer 7 content filtering, a few site-to-site VPNs if necessary, and easily enable some endpoint VPN clients (or an SSL-VPN portal that was... meh...).

Solutions like that are *never* going to be as comprehensive as a CLI-driven enterprise product with ultimate controllability. But those products take time to learn and expertise to manage properly. In Business, expertise costs money and time is a finite resource you can never regain. A lot of businesses cannot afford to dedicate a body to network engineering and need a handful of jack-of-all-trades sys admins to cover a wide variety of work that shifts on a daily basis. Giving those kinds of folks something they can pop into once every few months, easily grok via a GUI, make a few small tweaks, and then let it run "hands off" is valuable. ...And, in the early days, the SonicWall provided that. I just wish Dell hadn't slowly rotted them out.

15 years ago I was running an openBSD firewall router with my cable modem at the time. Like many people I moved to a cheaper dedicated router instead to a stand alone PC.

I’m SERIOUSLY thinking of going back to that sort of setup.

It’s a pain in the ass to be rolling your own stuff but the security is arguably better.

I'm still using Linux as an external firewall/router. If it's not listening on any external ports, and you're administering it via SSH on the internal interface, by the time anyone can get in to modify it, your network is thoroughly compromised anyway.

Or, of course, there's a zero-day in the Linux networking stack. But if that bites you, it will also bite hundreds of millions of juicier targets, so you might have time to get patched before getting owned. Maybe.

You can use an old desktop in that role, or you can choose from quite a number of small x86 boxes with a fairly fast CPU and multiple network ports, often in a NUC-like form factor. I was using a home Atom box (I think maybe a D550?) to firewall gigabit Internet for about five years, and it worked beautifully. Until it suddenly failed completely, anyway, which I gather is a thing that happened a lot with some generations of Atom. They just ... failed after four or five years, and that bit me too.

At the time, Atoms had weak floating point, but strong integer performance and a ton of bandwidth, so they ran iptables and routing code really fast. That was a sweet little firewall, and could comfortably push a gigabit both ways. I think it cost about $500 at the time(2010ish) but that was in a 1U rackmount case with an extra two-port NIC on a riser cable. You can get much nicer all-in-one units now, for a fair bit less.
